query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
1 Poscia che l’accoglienze oneste e liete 2 furo iterate tre e quattro volte, 3 Sordel si trasse, e disse: «Voi, chi siete?».
query.result:
**English:**
1 After the courteous and joyful greetings 2 had been repeated three and four times, 3 Sordello stepped forward and said: "Who are you?".
**Old English:**
1 Æfter ðæm ðe ða arwurðan and ða bliðan wilcuman 2 wæron ðriwa and feowersiðum awende, 3 Sordel him togeanes eode and cwæð: "Hwa synd ge?".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
4 «Anzi che a questo monte fosser volte 5 l’anime degne di salire a Dio, 6 fur l’ossa mie per Ottavian sepolte.
query.result:
**English:**
4 Before souls worthy of ascending to God 5 had turned to this mountain, 6 my bones were buried by Octavian.
**Old English:**
4 Ǣr ðon ðe ða gastas ðe ðam beorgum ārās, 5 ða ðe wæron wyrðe ðæs ðe hi to Gode ferdon, 6 wæron mīne bān bebyrgede fram Octaviano.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
7 Io son Virgilio; e per null’ altro rio 8 lo ciel perdei che per non aver fé». 9 Così rispuose allora il duca mio.
query.result:
**English:**
7 I am Virgil; and through no other fault 8 did I lose heaven than through not having faith." 9 Thus replied then my leader.
**Old English:**
7 Ic eom Virgilius; and ðurh nân ôðer unriht 8 ðone heofon ic forleas ðonne ðurh ungeleaffulnesse." 9 Swâ andswarode ðâ mîn lâreow.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
10 Qual è colui che cosa innanzi sé 11 sùbita vede ond’ e’ si maraviglia, 12 che crede e non, dicendo «Ella è . . . non è . . . »,
13 tal parve quelli; e poi chinò le ciglia, 14 e umilmente ritornò ver’ lui, 15 e abbracciòl là ’ve ’l minor s’appiglia.
query.result:
**English:**
10 Like someone who sees something ahead of him 11 suddenly and marvels at it, 12 so that he believes and disbelieves, saying, “It is . . . it is not . . . ”,
13 such he appeared; and then he lowered his brows, 14 and humbly returned toward him, 15 and embraced him where the lesser man clings.
**Old English:**
10 Swylce se ðe ðing beforan him 11 færlice gesihð ðe hine wundrige, 12 ðæt he gelyfeð and ne gelyfeð, secgende “Hit is . . . nis hit . . . ”,
13 swylc he ðuhte; and ða his neb he nyðerde, 14 and eadmodlice ongean hine gecerde, 15 and clypte hine ðær ðe se læssa wæs fæst.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
16 «O gloria di Latin», disse, «per cui 17 mostrò ciò che potea la lingua nostra, 18 o pregio etterno del loco ond’ io fui,
19 qual merito o qual grazia mi ti mostra? 20 S’io son d’udir le tue parole degno, 21 dimmi se vien d’inferno, e di qual chiostra».
query.result:
**English:**
16 "O glory of the Latin tongue," he said, "through whom 17 our language showed its power, 18 O eternal honor of the place from which I come,
19 what merit or what grace shows you to me? 20 If I am worthy to hear your words, 21 tell me if you come from hell, and from what circle."
**Old English:**
16 "O wuldor Lædene gereorde," cwæð he, "ðurh ðone 17 æteowde ðæt ðære spræce miht, 18 ece wurðmynt ðæs stowe ðanon ic com,
19 hwæt me geearnunge oððe hwæt me gife ðe æteowde? 20 Gif ic ðinra worda hyran weorðe eom, 21 sege me gif ðu of helle come, and of hwylcere cleofan."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
22 «Per tutt’ i cerchi del dolente regno», 23 rispuose lui, «son io di qua venuto; 24 virtù del ciel mi mosse, e con lei vegno.
query.result:
**English:**
22 "Through all the circles of the sorrowful kingdom," 23 he answered him, "I have come here; 24 the power of heaven moved me, and with it I come.
**Old English:**
22 "Þurh ealle hringas hellegrundes," 23 andswarode he him, "ic eom hider cumen; 24 miht meofones me hider sende, and his ellen deore."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
25 Non per far, ma per non fare ho perduto 26 a veder l’alto Sol che tu disiri 27 e che fu tardi per me conosciuto.
query.result:
**English:**
25 Not for doing, but for not doing have I lost 26 the sight of the high Sun which you desire 27 and which was recognized by me too late.
**Old English:**
25 Nis for ðon ðæt ic ða dede, ac for ðon ðæt ic hit ne dyde, 26 ðæt ic ðone hean Sun sceolde forleosan, 27 ðone ðu wilnast, and ðe wæs to ðæs læt gemeted.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
28 Luogo è là giù non tristo di martìri, 29 ma di tenebre solo, ove i lamenti 30 non suonan come guai, ma son sospiri.
query.result:
**English:**
28 There is a place down there, not sad with martyrs, 29 but only dark, where the lamentations 30 do not sound like wails, but are sighs.
**Old English:**
28 Þær is stede be neðan ðæm ne beoð martyrware, 29 ac ðeah is þær sweart gen雾g, ðær ða sorhfullan 30 ne wepað ac hweopð ða wædleasan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
37 Ma se tu sai e puoi, alcuno indizio 38 dà noi per che venir possiam più tosto 39 là dove purgatorio ha dritto inizio».
query.result:
**English:**
37 But if you know and are able, give us some indication 38 by which we can come more quickly 39 to where Purgatory rightly begins.
**Old English:**
37 Ac gif ðu wast and meaht, sumne wisan 38 tæc us ðurh ðone we ðy ðæs ðe hraðor 39 ðær ðær ðæs feorhclanunges rihte ordfruma is.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
43 Ma vedi già come dichina il giorno, 44 e andar sù di notte non si puote; 45 però è buon pensar di bel soggiorno.
query.result:
**English:**
43 But see how the day declines, 44 and traveling at night is impossible; 45 therefore it is wise to think of a good resting place.
**Old English:**
43 Ac geseoh nu ða hwær ðe dæg declineð, 44 and on niht ne mæg man faran; 45 forðæm is betere ðæt ðu ðe b宿n ðence.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
46 Anime sono a destra qua remote; 47 se mi consenti, io ti merrò ad esse, 48 e non sanza diletto ti fier note».
query.result:
**English:**
46 Souls are here on the right hand, set apart; 47 if you consent, I will lead you to them, 48 and they will not be unpleasing to you to know."
**Old English:**
46 Sawla syndon on ðære swiðran healfe toforan; 47 gif ðu ðafast, ic ðe ðider gelæde, 48 and ðe ne beoð unleoſe ðe to witanne."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
49 «Com’ è ciò?», fu risposto. «Chi volesse 50 salir di notte, fora elli impedito 51 d’altrui, o non sarria ché non potesse?».
query.result:
**English:**
49 "How is that?" was the answer. "If someone wanted 50 to climb at night, would he be prevented 51 by others, or would he not be able to do it?"
**Old English:**
49 "Hu is ðæt?" wæs ðæs andsware. "Gif hwá wolde 50 on niht astígan, wære he ðonne forð geswenced 51 ðurh óðre, oððe nære he ðæs mægenes?"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
52 E ’l buon Sordello in terra fregò ’l dito, 53 dicendo: «Vedi? sola questa riga 54 non varcheresti dopo ’l sol partito:
55 non però ch’altra cosa desse briga, 56 che la notturna tenebra, ad ir suso; 57 quella col nonpoder la voglia intriga.
query.result:
**English:**
52 And the good Sordello traced his finger on the ground, 53 saying: "See? You would not cross this line alone 54 after the sun has set,
55 not because anything else would hinder you, 56 except the darkness of the night, from going up; 57 that, with its powerlessness, entangles the will.
**Old English:**
52 And se goda Sordello on eorðan fæste his finger, 53 cweðende: "Gesyhst ðu? ðeos anhaga 54 ne oferwundest ðu æfter ðære sunnan setle:
55 na forðæm ðe oðer ðing bryce, 56 buton ðære nihtlican þýstro, ðe ðe ne læt upp astigan; 57 ðæt mid unmihte ðone willan bewerigð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
58 Ben si poria con lei tornare in giuso 59 e passeggiar la costa intorno errando, 60 mentre che l’orizzonte il dì tien chiuso».
query.result:
**English:**
58 One could indeed return below with her 59 and wander, straying along the coast, 60 while the horizon still holds the day captive.
**Old English:**
58 Man mæg mid hyre eft ongean faran 59 and ymb ða sælade wandrian, 60 ða hwile ðe ðæs dæges eag byð locen.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
61 Allora il mio segnor, quasi ammirando, 62 «Menane», disse, «dunque là ’ve dici 63 ch’aver si può diletto dimorando».
query.result:
**English:**
61 Then my lord, as if in wonder, 62 said, "Lead me, then, to where you say 63 one can find delight in dwelling."
**Old English:**
61 Þa min hlaford, swilce wundrigende, 62 "Læð ðu," cwæð he, "me ðonne ðær ðu segst 63 ðæt mon mæg wynlicor wunian."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
64 Poco allungati c’eravam di lici, 65 quand’ io m’accorsi che ’l monte era scemo, 66 a guisa che i vallon li sceman quici.
query.result:
**English:**
64 We had climbed a little farther up, 65 when I noticed that the mountain was cut off, 66 just as valleys are cut off here.
**Old English:**
64 We hæfdon lyt ðanon geliðen, 65 ða ic ongeat ðæt ðe munt wæs sceacen, 66 swylce ða denu her doð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
67 «Colà», disse quell’ ombra, «n’anderemo 68 dove la costa face di sé grembo; 69 e là il novo giorno attenderemo».
query.result:
**English:**
67 "Over there," said that shade, "we will go 68 where the coast makes a lap of itself; 69 and there we will await the new day."
**Old English:**
67 "Þider," cwæð se sceaða, "we sceolon faran, 68 þær se clif on hwærf weorðeð næsse; 69 and þær ðone niwan dæg abídan."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
70 Tra erto e piano era un sentiero schembo, 71 che ne condusse in fianco de la lacca, 72 là dove più ch’a mezzo muore il lembo.
query.result:
**English:**
70 Across the bank and level was a winding path, 71 which led us to the side of the hollow, 72 where the hillside dies away more than halfway down.
**Old English:**
70 Ofer ðone munt and ofer ðone mearc scearpne, 71 ðe us on ða laðe stede gelædde, 72 ðær ðæs helles muða ðurh ðone mist hlynsode.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
73 Oro e argento fine, cocco e biacca, 74 indaco, legno lucido e sereno, 75 fresco smeraldo in l’ora che si fiacca,
76 da l’erba e da li fior, dentr’ a quel seno 77 posti, ciascun saria di color vinto, 78 come dal suo maggiore è vinto il meno.
query.result:
**English:**
73 Gold and fine silver, cochineal and white lead, 74 indigo, bright and clear wood, 75 fresh emerald at the hour when it breaks,
76 placed by the grass and flowers, within that bosom, 77 each would be vanquished in color, 78 as the lesser is vanquished by its greater.
**Old English:**
73 Gold and seolfres sinc, seolfor and read gold, 74 geap and gimcyn, græg and heorugrim, 75 smaragdus se gebrocen wyrðeð,
76 on þam wongstede, and þa wyrta geond þæt feld, 77 æghwylc wære gelicost, þeah he hit gesawon hæbbe, 78 swa bið se læssa of þam mæran oferwunnen.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
79 Non avea pur natura ivi dipinto, 80 ma di soavità di mille odori 81 vi facea uno incognito e indistinto.
query.result:
**English:**
79 Nature alone had not painted there, 80 but with the sweetness of a thousand scents 81 it made there an unknown and indistinct [harmony].
**Old English:**
79 Nis ðær næfre gesewen swylc wudu, 80 ac ðær wæs swetnes monigfealdra blóstma, 81 ðe ðær wæron uncuðe and ungelice.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
82 ‘Salve, Regina’ in sul verde e ’n su’ fiori 83 quindi seder cantando anime vidi, 84 che per la valle non parean di fuori.
query.result:
**English:**
82 ‘Hail, Queen’ on the green grass and on the flowers 83 then I saw souls sitting and singing, 84 who did not appear outside for the valley.
**Old English:**
82 ‘Hal wes þu, Cwen’ on þam grene and on þam blostmum 83 þær ic sittende sawla geseah, 84 þe ne wæron on þære dene ute.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
85 «Prima che ’l poco sole omai s’annidi», 86 cominciò ’l Mantoan che ci avea vòlti, 87 «tra color non vogliate ch’io vi guidi.
query.result:
**English:**
85 "Before the little sun sets," 86 began the Mantuan who had turned us, 87 "do not ask me to guide you among those."
**Old English:**
85 "Ær ðon ðæt lytle sunne nu ætsitt", 86 ongan ða Mantuan ðe usic wende, 87 "betwux ða ne willað ðe ic eow læde."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
88 Di questo balzo meglio li atti e ’ volti 89 conoscerete voi di tutti quanti, 90 che ne la lama giù tra essi accolti.
query.result:
**English:**
88 Of this cliff you will better know the deeds and faces 89 of all those than you would 90 down in the valley where they are gathered together.
**Old English:**
88 Þisses clifes be beteran ða deda and ða wlite 89 cunnan georne ðonne ge ealle, 90 ðe on ðam wæle nyðer sind genumen.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
91 Colui che più siede alto e fa sembianti 92 d’aver negletto ciò che far dovea, 93 e che non move bocca a li altrui canti,
94 Rodolfo imperador fu, che potea 95 sanar le piaghe c’hanno Italia morta, 96 sì che tardi per altri si ricrea.
query.result:
**English:**
91 He who sits highest and makes a show 92 of having neglected what he should have done, 93 and who does not move his mouth to the songs of others,
94 was Emperor Rudolf, who could have healed 95 the wounds that have killed Italy, 96 so that she might be revived later by others.
**Old English:**
91 Se ðe hehst sitteð and ðone hiw mæneð 92 ðæt he forgeaf ðæt he gefremedon sceolde, 93 and ðæs oðres songes muð ne ontyneð,
94 ðæt wæs Rodulfus se casere, se ðe Rome 95 ða wunda gehælde ðe ða wæl slegen 96 ðurh ðæs folces syn, ða hit forloren wæs.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
97 L’altro che ne la vista lui conforta, 98 resse la terra dove l’acqua nasce 99 che Molta in Albia, e Albia in mar ne porta:
100 Ottacchero ebbe nome, e ne le fasce 101 fu meglio assai che Vincislao suo figlio 102 barbuto, cui lussuria e ozio pasce.
query.result:
**English:**
97 The other, who comforted him with his gaze, 98 ruled the land where the water rises 99 that the Moldau carries into the Elbe, and the Elbe into the sea:
100 Ottokar was his name, and in his swaddling clothes 101 he was far better than his son Wenceslas, 102 the bearded one, whom luxury and idleness feed.
**Old English:**
97 Se ðe oðer ðe hine on ðære gesihðe getrymde, 98 heold ða eorðan ðær ðæt wæter cymð 99 ðe Molda on Elfe bryð, and Elfe on sæ lædeð:
100 Ottocer hatte, and on ðam swidelum 101 wæs he betera micle ðonne his sunu Wencislaus, 102 se beardes man, ðone ofermetto and idelnes fedæð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
103 E quel nasetto che stretto a consiglio 104 par con colui c’ha sì benigno aspetto, 105 morì fuggendo e disfiorando il giglio:
106 guardate là come si batte il petto! 107 L’altro vedete c’ha fatto a la guancia 108 de la sua palma, sospirando, letto.
query.result:
**English:**
103 And that little nose that, taking counsel with itself, 104 seems like the one who has such a kind appearance, 105 died fleeing and disfiguring the lily:
106 look there how he beats his chest! 107 You see the other who has made of his palm, sighing, a bed for his cheek.
**Old English:**
103 And ðæt næseðæt ðæt ðurh ræd geðohte 104 ðuhte ðæm gelic ðe ðæs anlicnes wæs, 105 forðferde fleonde and ðone lilian aweste:
106 lociað ðær hu he ðone breost beateð! 107 ðone oðerne ðe ða ðone wlitegan wang 108 mid ðære folman, siccetende, oferwrah.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
109 Padre e suocero son del mal di Francia: 110 sanno la vita sua viziata e lorda, 111 e quindi viene il duol che sì li lancia.
query.result:
**English:**
109 Father and father-in-law are of the evil of France: 110 they know his corrupt and filthy life, 111 and hence comes the grief that so torments them.
**Old English:**
109 Fæder and swegr fæder sindon ðæs yfeles of Francena: 110 hi witon ðæs lifes his gewemmede and gewemmede, 111 and ðanon cymð ðæt hearm ðe hi swa hreowað.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
121 Rade volte risurge per li rami 122 l’umana probitate; e questo vole 123 quei che la dà, perché da lui si chiami.
query.result:
**English:**
121 Human goodness rarely rises again through the branches, 122 and this is what he who gives it wants, 123 so that it may be called his gift.
**Old English:**
121 Selden arist on ðam telgum 122 monnes manngifu; ðæt is ðæs monnes willan, 123 ðæt he his gifu ðurh ðone mon sylle.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
124 Anche al nasuto vanno mie parole 125 non men ch’a l’altro, Pier, che con lui canta, 126 onde Puglia e Proenza già si dole.
query.result:
**English:**
124 My words also go to the snub-nosed one, 125 no less than to the other, Pier, who sings with him, 126 because of whom Apulia and Provence are already grieving.
**Old English:**
124 Eac ða word to ðam hnutan nosan 125 na læs ðonne ðam oðrum, Peotr, ðe mid him singð, 126 ðurh ða Apulia and Provens ða wop wæron.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
127 Tant’ è del seme suo minor la pianta, 128 quanto, più che Beatrice e Margherita, 129 Costanza di marito ancor si vanta.
query.result:
**English:**
127 So much smaller is the plant than its seed, 128 as Constance still boasts of her husband, 129 more than Beatrice and Margaret.
**Old English:**
127 Swa micle is ðæs sædes sæd læsse, 128 swa ðe ma ðonne Beatris and Margarete, 129 Costanza ðæs weres wyrðeð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
130 Vedete il re de la semplice vita 131 seder là solo, Arrigo d’Inghilterra: 132 questi ha ne’ rami suoi migliore uscita.
query.result:
**English:**
130 See the king of the simple life 131 sit there alone, Henry of England: 132 he has a better outcome in his branches.
**Old English:**
130 Geseoð ðone cyning ðære anfealde lifes 131 sittan ðær ana, Henric of Englene: 132 he hæfð on his bogum bettre ende.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
133 Quel che più basso tra costor s’atterra, 134 guardando in suso, è Guiglielmo marchese, 135 per cui e Alessandria e la sua guerra
136 fa pianger Monferrato e Canavese».
query.result:
**English:**
133 He who lies lowest among them, 134 looking up, is Marquis Guglielmo, 135 because of whom Alessandria and its war
136 make Monferrato and Canavese weep.
**Old English:**
133 Se ðe lægsta ðara ðe ðær licgað, 134 uppweard besceawiende, is Willelm marchio, 135 ðurh ðone Alexandria and ðære gewinn
136 deð Monferrat and Canaveys wepan.
